channel.title: Show when logged out?
channel.description:
Hey how do you make it show all players when some1 has logged out? Just like when people log in it says playerName+ " has logged in! There are now " +playerCount+ "players..."
Any1 know?

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @kniveslives kniveslives
item.description:
@kniveslives wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:26, topic:159393”]Oh. Yes.
Hahahahahaha.
Above logout();
PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName + " has logged out! There are now " + PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount() + " players online!";[/quote]

Okay thank you, this problem was solved, it works now.

Read full topic

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @kniveslives kniveslives
item.description:
@kniveslives wrote:

There is also this:

case 9154: //LOG OUT
{
logout();
savemoreinfo();
}
break;

Is that what I need?

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @kniveslives kniveslives
item.description:
@kniveslives wrote:

switch(packetType) {
case 0: break; // idle packet - keeps on reseting timeOutCounter

		case 202:			// idle logout packet - ignore for now
                            logout();
			break;

That is what I get, is that what you were looking for?

Read full topic

I have a right to be all pissy. Calling a method is simple. If you cannot work that out, and how it works then you should give up, now.

Search for this EXACTLY;
logout();

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

For fuck sakes.
The method logout() must be called within your code - with logout();
E.g;
if(blah.equals(blah)) {
methodCall();
}

Calls the method methodCall(), so like this;

public void methodCall() {
System.out.println(“lelelelle it has been called l0lr”);
}

When methodCall() is called, it will print; lelelelle it has been called l0lr

Read full topic

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @kniveslives kniveslives
item.description:
@kniveslives wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:12, topic:159393”][quote author=kniveslives link=topic=217054.msg1889291#msg1889291 date=1195642854]

Look for

public void logout()

And inside of that method (a void is a return-type for a method, just to let you know) put:

PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName+" has logged out! There are now "+PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount()+" players online!"

I tried that, it says “Null has logged out” and so forth, it doesn’t say the players name, I’m pretty sure I entered it right.

{
PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName+" has logged out! There are now “+PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount()+” players online!";
}
[/quote]
That’s because the playerName string has just been “un assigned”.
Before you call logout(), add that.[/quote]

Sorry I don’t really understand that, I’ve never done this before, so please bare with me, I have this:

public void logout(){
	outStream.createFrame(109);
}

{
PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName+" has logged out! There are now “+PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount()+” players online!";
}

Then after that it goes into commands, and above that is other stuff, be more thorough in your explanation please?

Read full topic

item.title: Show when logged out?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“kniveslives, post:9, topic:159393”][quote author=TeleNubby link=topic=217054.msg1889263#msg1889263 date=1195641022]
Look for

public void logout()

And inside of that method (a void is a return-type for a method, just to let you know) put:

PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName+" has logged out! There are now "+PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount()+" players online!"

[/quote]

I tried that, it says “Null has logged out” and so forth, it doesn’t say the players name, I’m pretty sure I entered it right.

{
PlayerHandler.messageToAll = playerName+" has logged out! There are now “+PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount()+” players online!";
}[/quote]
That’s because the playerName string has just been “un assigned”.
Before you call logout(), add that.

Read full topic
